newsitem.title: MOZAMBIQUE: Mozambique's Chissano re-elected ruling party head.
newsitem.headline: Mozambique's Chissano re-elected ruling party head.

text.p: Mozambique's ruling Frelimo Party has re-elected head of state Joaquim Chissano as president of the party, a Frelimo spokesman said on Saturday.
The election of the president and other members of the Frelimo Central Committee took place on Friday night at the end of a one-week party congress.
The election ended Mozambican press speculation during the congress that Chissano would step down as party leader, to cultivate the image of a state president above party politics.
This proved unfounded and Chissano stood unopposed.
Of the 653 votes cast, 641 were for Chissano. Three ballot papers were spoiled and nine were blank.
Chissano, 58, was a founder member of Frelimo, created in 1962 to fight for independence from Portugal.

He became foreign minister at independence in 1975 and president of the republic and the party in 1986 when Mozambique was a one-party state, on the death in a plane crash of his predecessor Samora Machel.
After leading the country into a multi-party system, he won a first-round victory in presidential elections in 1994, after a long civil war.
This week's party congress, the seventh since 1962, was held in a huge tent at Matola, an industrial town on the outskirts of the capital Maputo.
The election of Chissano as party leader increases the likelihood of his selection as Frelimo candidate for the next state presidential elections, scheduled for 1999.
